tweets.text: Today is the International Day of Women and Girls in Science. #DYK that 60% of our employees and 18 managers in 35 are women? Here at #EFSA we celebrate our #WomenInScience! #WomenAndGirlsInScience @UN_Women https://t.co/NllQ7amxNf

The new batch of #data means that more than half of the surveys in EFSA‚Äôs database covering infants, toddlers, adolescents, adults and special groups were carried out using the #EUMenu methodology. Which means‚Ä¶ https://t.co/176pwPQn6K

But it‚Äôs not cheap. Which is why EFSA offers #funding to countries that collect data using our harmonised method. Since 2011 we have provided financial support and guidance on #datacollection to 21 countries. https://t.co/oh0W7YuqDN

Standardising the way #data is collected makes the information easier to compare and improves the quality of #riskassessments that rely on dietary information. In particular, it reduces the use of assumptions and conservative estimates of risk in #foodsafety assessments. https://t.co/zcTznAWRms

The level of detail and the quality of the #data collected is also uneven, affected by differences in the survey design, the tools used to collect and measure the data, the clustering of age groups, and food description and categorisation systems. https://t.co/xcdS3hnnaE

Most European countries carry out dietary surveys, but the data cannot always be compared because of differences in collection methodologies. These range from recalling intake from the previous day (24-hour recall) to keeping a food ‚Äúdiary‚Äù over several days (dietary record). https://t.co/BOTULOMSar
